title: Manchester United and Liverpool stars past and present reveal their derby memories
text:
Manchester United are 15 points behind Liverpool after only eight games.

The north west giants meet at Old Trafford in the Premier League on Sunday,

Sportsmail spoke to past and present players at both clubs who told us what it’s like to be miles behind ‑ or ahead of ‑ your arch-rivals…

Gary Pallister powers home a header for Manchester United in a 3-1 win at Anfield in 1997

Largest margine between rivals since mid-80s

GORDON MCQUEEN (MANCHESTER UNITED - 229 GAMES, 1978-85)

The gap between the two clubs is bigger than at any time since I left United in 1985 and I can’t see anything changing in the near future, either.

People have talked about no United players getting into a combined XI from the two clubs and I can see that. Maybe David De Gea but no-one else and he’s injured for this one.

Gordon McQueen (left) is tackled by Mark Lawrenson during the League Cup final in 1983

It’s a huge gap between the two clubs. You only have to look at the points difference after eight or games of the season to see that.

In those days, the dominance of either club didn’t matter, but it does now because Liverpool are so much better.

Dominance didn’t matter then because we always felt we could get one over on Liverpool. In the 12 or 13 times I played against Liverpool, Ian Rush never scored against me.

The games against them were always very tight and you always looked forward to it as the biggest game in the football calendar — never mind Manchester City. It will be another huge game on Sunday.

This is the biggest match in the world, you dare not lose

PHIL THOMPSON (LIVERPOOL - 477 games, 1971-85)

It doesn’t matter one bit whether Liverpool or Manchester United are the more dominant going into this game. What matters most is that the players understand this is the biggest game in world football and they dare not lose.

My fear is that some of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s players will produce their best performance of the season and their fans will be asking ‘Where’s that been?’ That’s why Jordan Henderson and James Milner will be the most important players in Liverpool’s dressing room. Not Roberto Firmino, Sadio Mane or Virgil van Dijk because Henderson and Milner will underline what this game means.

Liverpool's Phil Thompson challenges Joe Jordan during the FA Cup semi-final in 1979

When United were dominant, Gary Neville would have been one of the first to go round the dressing room and kick-start the mind games with his teammates.

I made my debut at Old Trafford against George Best, Bobby Charlton and Denis Law and was shaking in awe at what I was going to face, but Bill Shankly gave us such belief that we won 3-0.

I can remember Roy Evans’s sides outplaying United but still losing. Ole is saying this can open the door to United’s season and he’s absolutely right. You can revel in being the the underdog for this fixture and Liverpool, as the favourite, have to be switched on.

Of course, yours truly has a pretty decent record in this game. Managing against Sir Alex Ferguson, we played two, won two. You just daren’t lose this game.

Liverpool was the only home game Fergie made us stay in a hotel

GARY PALLISTER (MANCHESTER UNITED - 437 GAMES , 1989-98)

We were dominant at the time but I will never forget the 3-3 draw at Anfield in 1994. At 3-0 up at half-time, we thought it was going to be a result to change the face of the fixture. It could have been five or six but Liverpool came back at us with verve.

So which one of us was the dominant club didn’t really count. When I arrived at United they actually had a decent record against Liverpool despite them being stronger. We held our own against them and that says a lot about the fixture.

It’s the most passionate and crazy of Premier League games. It means so much to the fans and it’s still the biggest one in the calendar because of the dominance of both clubs over the years — vying for bragging rights over who is most successful.

There was always a different feel to the game and a different preparation. It was the only time the manager took us away to a hotel before a home fixture.

We knew how big it was but he wanted us to know how significant it was to break the stranglehold they had. There was more pressure. You get caught up in the whole feel of it. You know what it means to the fans and the club is an awful place to be around when you lose that one.

It wouldn’t surprise me if United win this one and then lose at Norwich next week

CLAYTON BLACKMORE (MANCHESTER UNITED - 245 GAMES, 1982-94)

The weird thing is, when Liverpool were winning the league all the time we used to beat them and when we were winning the league all the time they used to beat us. I don’t know why, it’s a hard one to explain!

United-Liverpool is always the standout fixture but I’d give up winning the game to win the league.

The only goal I ever scored at Wembley was against Liverpool in the 1990 Charity Shield, but John Barnes equalised and we ended up sharing it — no penalty shootouts back then! Liverpool were the big team on the block at the time and they’re the best team around at the moment.

They will come at United tomorrow and that will leave more space for us.

United don’t do so well against teams that drop off because we struggle to break them down.

United have also got injuries to key players. Missing Paul Pogba in midfield is a big problem but Sergio Romero is a good reserve to come in for ’keeper David de Gea.

It wouldn’t surprise me if United win this one and then lose at Norwich the following week after playing a tricky away game in Belgrade against Partizan.

It didn't matter how bad United were, we had to beat them!

RONNIE WHELAN (LIVERPOOL - 493 games, 1979-94)

Whether Manchester United were tenth or second, it didn’t matter. We only ever had one thing in our mind — beat them, keep them at arm’s length.

We had a fantastic time in the 1980s and we dominated the league but never once did we take games against them for granted.

Manchester United's Paul Ince is blocked by Ronnie Whelan at Wembley in 1990

They had difficulties with consistency but they always had fantastic individuals, such as Bryan Robson, who had the potential to do damage. So when the fixtures came around, it was simply a case of getting three points and keeping them out of the way.

I always remember going to Old Trafford and you could feel the venom and hatred in the atmosphere. You knew how desperate they were to flatten us and if that didn’t give you an extra incentive to win, nothing would. The tension you felt beforehand couldn’t be compared. That’s what made the emotions around the results so acute. If you lost, the thought of going into work on Monday was awful. You could get over most defeats but not to them. But beating them? There’s nothing like it.

Did I ever think they would overhaul us? No. I remember 1985-86 when they started with 10 wins from 10 and everyone was a cock-a-hoop. We were never worried. The feeling was ‘we’ll be OK when we get going’. We were. We won the Double.

They were poor at Newcastle... so I'm expecting a reaction

ANDY ROBERTSON (LIVERPOOL - 90 games, 2017 -)

I don’t think it matters what your form is like for these games. It doesn’t matter that we’ve won eight on the bounce and they’re struggling. It’s Manchster United versus Liverpool.

I have no doubt they will produce a reaction after a poor performance against Newcastle. They will be firing and wanting to kick-start their season. There would be no better time to do it than against us. But we have our own objectives and our own aims. That’s what we are striving for.

What makes the game so special is that it’s historic. There have been so many great battles down the years between top teams who have always fought for everything on the pitch. It’s genuinely a different atmosphere — but a good one. There is always an edge to it.

It’s a nice, historic stadium, although I prefer Anfield!
